Warren Buffett's message is not upbeat. Period. We are witnessing a classic example of a veteran recognizing that when risks are hard to quantify, it's best to err on the side of conservatism and not add to equities. Rather, saving money for a rainy day, is preferable.

In press release, Berkshire sold $6.4 billion in equities during the month of April.
Bingo.

Though Warren says never bet against America, he has not year to date in 2020. In the first quarter of 2020 he only purchased $1.85 billion of equities (net) and only bought back $1.62 billion of Berkshire stock. In April he sold nearly $6.5 billion of equities at Berkshire.

Taken together, Berkshire has SOLD $3 billion net in equities year to date - despite the market's decline. There is only one conclusion: The Oracle of Omaha is not bullish, near term, on equities. @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @beckyquick @andrewrsorkin

None, whatsover Adrian. The greatest of all time. But Berkshire is now penalized by its own remarkable success - it has grown too large to relatively perform... @tomkeene @jimcramer @SquawkCNBC
Res ipsa loquitor. @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @lizclaman @SquawkCNBC @riskrversal @Sarge986 @terranovajoe @andrewrsorkin @beckyquick

Warren Buffett, as measured by his Partnership and Berkshire's average annual return over sixty years, is the greatest investor in the modern era. But make no mistake about it, Berkshire is too big to be relatively successful (against the averages or GDP) - and the performance

over the last three, five or seven years is testimony to that. As to the critics of Berkshire and Warren's long term investing style - well that is laughable. And I automatically intellectually and physically block those glib hotshots who dismiss Warren as an investment genius.
8 minutes for the Berkshire Annual Meeting with the greatest modern era investor, Warren Buffett....

@Convertbond @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC Here is a question that I intended to ask in 2013, but we ran out of time... Unasked Question No. 1-- Is Berkshire Too Big to Outperform? Historically, Berkshire's outperformance over the past 40-plus years has been spectacular.

However, sustaining that growth is becoming more difficult to achieve. You noted in your 2007 annual letter that, "Berkshire's past record can't be duplicated or even approached." And in almost every letter since that, you have uttered the same theme. In the sole year of the last

four (in 2011) that Berkshire succeeded in outperforming the share price of the S&P 500, it did so by a mere 2.5%. Even five years ago (in 2008), when performance was strong on a relative basis, Berkshire still recorded a negative return of -9.6% (while the S&P dropped by a

staggering -37%). Explain how Berkshire can persist in outperforming the markets while you continue to expand the size of your company Note: This question (one of my top six initially) was somewhat close to Carol Loomis's first question, so I canned it. @andrewrsorkin @beckyquick
Thanks.
that was my #1.
Here were the questions I asked of Warren and Charlie at the 2013 Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting on @realmoney realmoney.thestreet.com/artiâ€¦

@Convertbond @jimcramer @tomkeene As Warren Buffett has said himself repeatedly, we structured Berkshire Hathaway "not to blow it." Berkshire Hathaway is at best a S&P performer, as measured by sales and profit growth or book value change - just look at 3, 5 year performance.

has begun to resemble an index fund that is more appropriate for widows and orphans rather than past investors who sought out differentiated and superior compounded growth? In the past, you have quoted Benjamin Graham, saying "price is what you pay -- value is what you get." Are

your recent deals and large investments bringing Berkshire less value than the deals done previously? A: Warren admitted that Berkshire won't grow as rapidly in the future as it has in the past but it will still generate a lot of incremental value. "We think we will do better

than the giants of the past," he said. Charlie chimed in and said much of the same. Warren then exclaimed, "Doug, you haven't convinced me to sell the stock, but keep trying! @Convertbond @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @andrewrsorkin @riskreversal @beckquick

Lawrence this was the exact point I made when I was on the dais with Warren and Charlie at the 2013 Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting in Omaha: I started by thanking Charlie and Warren for the invitation and told them that I was honored. Then I said that I looked forward to

playing the role of "Daniel in the lion's den" in front of over 30,000 of his closest friends and greatest admirers. (That got a cheer!) Question No. 1 -- Size Matters Q: As it is said, Warren, "Size matters!" In the past, Berkshire bought cheap or wholesale -- for instance,

Geico, MidAmerican Energy, the initial Coca-Cola (KO) purchase and Benjamin Moore. Arguably, your company has shifted to becoming a buyer of pricier and more mature businesses -- for instance, IBM (IBM), Burlington Northern Santa Fe, Heinz (HNZ) and Lubrizol, which were done at

prices to sales, earnings and book value multiples well above the prior acquisitions and after the stock prices rose. Many of the recent buys might be great additions to Berkshire's portfolio of companies, however, the relatively high prices paid for these investments could

potentially result in a lower return on invested capital. In the past you hunted gazelles, but now you are hunting elephants. To me, the recent buys look like preparation for your legacy, creating a more mature, slower-growing enterprise. Is Berkshire morphing into a stock that

Here is Gundlach's tweet - if correct, hugely important.

@realmoney Gundlach is now out after the close on Friday, saying the Fed has not yet bought a single piece of paper, and it has all been a big trick of moral suasion. If anyone knows, it should be him. There is a chance he is right, because the Fed buying any risky assets

would in fact be illegal. I am a big believer in what moral suasion can do (unfortunately), however I do not think it is that powerful. But now we get to find out. If he is right, and people realize they have been hoodwinked into thinking they were backstopped and that the Fed

was in there buying, the bottom will fall out of all this stuff Monday morning. Individual bonds, and of course things like the $HYG ETF. All I know is if I owned $HYG, I would be selling it first thing Monday AM and not waiting to find out. Itâ€™s not like it can really trade

up in any material fashion either, so all you would be doing is forgoing interest for a short period of time until things settle out and you know for sure. Last one out is a rotten egg! Sort of like if you owned $TSLA, the second Muskâ€™s tweet came out you should have hit the

eject button instead of waiting to see how the stock reacted to that tweet! If credit sells off the stock market will too, and the VIX will spike, and a ton of trades will get unwound. Since the market seems to move 2-3% on a normal day now (which is crazy in and of itself),

this could be good for a bigger down move than that, and it could happen over a few days. Or this will in fact cause the Fed to actually step in Monday morning, and actually get their hands dirty and do what is specifically deemed illegal under the Federal Reserve Act of 1913.

So I guess we will see. He has a big mouthpiece. This is out there now. nitter.net/TruthGundlach/stâ€¦ @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @bobpisani @riskreversal @terranovajoe @guyadami @ritholtz @Sarge986 @lizclaman @ScottWapnerCNBC @michaelsantoli @carlquintanilla

I have expressed my dissatisfaction regarding Kernan's hurtful ad hominem attacks on me before to Mark Hoffman the president of CNBC. I have done this again, Jerry. If I don't get a formal apology I am "going to get medieval on his ass" by exposing him and his antics.

piped.video/watch?v=1m24c5TRâ€¦ I have responded in kinds with the facts - that I have made sizable gains being long $AMZN over the last seventeen months. I have conveyed my analysis, tapes of tv interviews, etc. yet he continues to use the bully pulpit in projecting baseless, fictional

claims that I have been a bear and lost money on $Amzn - when the stock has been one of my greatest all time winners. But his obsession with me, like that of Alan Abelson in Barrons (when he was alive) @ritholtz and others have been consistent and conspicuous and goes well

beyond his fictional claims regarding my investments in Amazon. @SquawkCNBC @andrewrsorkin @BeckyQuick Normally, it would be a waste of time for me to tweet this out but I feel I must defend myself against baseless claims and call out someone who resides in the cheap seats of
hate, who apparently can only give a check (and cant take one) and who is not even a player in the arena.
end.

@realmoney May 01, 2020 | 04:09 PM EDT DOUG KASS Wrapping Up a Busy Week and Staying Transparent Thanks for reading my Diary today and all week. It's been a long five days and I am going to sign off early. This has been a difficult period for many and I have tried to unemotion

ally explain how I am navigating and coping with the markets (and life). As you can read, I am trading more than I have in a long time. I end the day in market neutral exposure -- as we sit on my intrinsic value calculus at 2800. I covered my large ($SPY) short today as we moved

to 2800 level I sold half of my SPY puts, for a nice gain as well. I tend to use puts with a very short term trading leash given the decay in premium if market direction moves against me This week I sold out of ($FDX) , ($DIS) , ($MS) and all my energy trading long rentals.

$XOM $XLE $HAL 1-2 weeks ago I sold out my entire $AMZN $GOOGL. My portfolio now consists of a very large exposure in financials (which I believe trade at a S&P equivalent of 2200 or less), several special situations (value oriented) longs and a medium-sized SPY put position

against them. My gross exposure is back to a low level -- not surprising considering the economic and health uncertainties and the closeness of the S&P to fair market value. My guess is that I will be selling my SPY puts sometime next week -- win, lose or draw -- as these are

intended as short-term rentals and not long-term leases. Theta (decay of option premium) risk. Also, I am short Apple ($AAPL) and Caterpillar ($CAT) . @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @jimcramer @tomkeene @lizclaman @riskreversal @terranovajoe @guyadami @bobpisani

Its simple. I have endured enough unprovoked attacks from Kernan over the years. He has an apparent obsession about me (as he did with Barrons Alan Abelson and others over the years). I have again taken it to his superior (Mark Hoffman, chairman of @CNBC who is a good guy) and
if I dont get a public apology from him I will take it in my own hands. End of message. @beckyquick
